image.caption: Collection of the U.S. House of Representatives

profileText: (Son of Hiram Bingham), a Representative from New York; born in New Haven, Conn., April 24, 1914; attended Groton School; graduated from Yale University, New Haven, Conn., 1936; graduated fromYale Law School, New Haven, Conn., 1939; lawyer, private practice; commenced practice in New York City; admitted to the New York bar in 1940; private in the United States Army in April 1943, and was discharged as a captain in October 1945, with War Department Staff Citation; special assistant to Assistant Secretary of State in 1945 and 1946; deputy administrator, Technical Cooperation Administration, 1951-1953; secretary to Governor Averell Harriman, 1955-1958; United States representative on United Nations Trusteeship Council with rank of Minister in 1961 and 1962 and serving as president in 1962; United States representative on United Nations Economic and Social Council with rank of Ambassador in 1963 and 1964; United States delegate to four United Nations General Assemblies; elected as a Democrat to the Eighty-ninth and to the eight succeeding Congresses (January 3, 1965-January 3, 1983); was not a candidate for reelection in 1982; was a resident of the Bronx, N.Y., until his death in New York City, on July 3, 1986.

creativeWork.freeFormCitationText: Ralph Nader Congress Project. Citizens Look at Congress: Jonathan B. Bingham, Democratic Representative from New York. Washington, D. C.: Grossman Publishers, 1972.

researchRecord.name: ca. 1965-1983, 470 cubic feet..
researchRecord.description: The papers of Jonathan Brewster Bingham spans the entire public career and include personal and official papers and correspondence.

researchRecord.name: 1975, 22 pages.
researchRecord.description: An oral history interview of Jonathan Brewster Bingham by Judith Goldstein conducted in 1975. Topics covered in the interview include the resettling Russian emigrees in Israel, earmarking appropriations, and congressional sympathy for Israel. Other subjects include the Jackson amendment, United States support for aid to Israel, and lobbying for Irish, Greek and other ethnic groups.

researchRecord.name: In the Oral History of Groton School Collection, 1885-1985, 10 linear feet.
researchRecord.description: Interviewees include Jonathan Brewster Bingham. A finding aid for the collection is available in the library.

researchRecord.name: 1967, 0.3 linear foot.
researchRecord.description: The papers consist of press releases of Congressman Jonathan Brewster Bingham from 1967. An unpublished guide for the papers is available in the repository.

researchRecord.name: In the New York State Records of Governor Averell Harriman, 1954-1958. 740 feet.
1970, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A letter between Jonathan Brewster Bingham and Marian Anderson.
